article.title: Effects of dust evolution on the abundances of CO and H$_2$

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements about the dust-to-gas ratio (D) is **incorrect** according to Figure 1?
choices: The dust-to-gas ratio is dominated by large grains at low metallicities.
The dust-to-gas ratio increases steeply around Z ~ 0.1-0.2 Z.
The total dust-to-gas ratio is determined by the balance between accretion and SN destruction at high metallicities.
The small grain component always dominates the dust-to-gas ratio at all metallicities.

multiple_choice_question.text: At which metallicity does a cloud with a typical density and column density of Milky Way \'molecular\' clouds become fully molecular (fH2 ~ 1)?
choices: Z ~ 0.1 Zo
Z ~ 0.4 Zo
Z ~ Zo

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main shielding component for CO formation at metallicities above 0.2 Zo?
choices: H2 self-shielding
CO self-shielding
Dust shielding
None of the above

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is the CO-to-H2 conversion factor (Xco) sensitive to metallicity?
choices: Because the CO abundance is always higher than the H2 abundance at all metallicities.
Because there is a metallicity range where the cloud is rich in H2 but not in CO.
Because the CO abundance does not depend on dust abundance.
Because the CO J=1â†’0 line is never optically thick.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 2a, what is the primary driver of increased H2 fraction in a cloud with a column density of NH = 1021 cm-2 at low metallicities?
choices: CO self-shielding
Increase in UV radiation field
Increase in dust abundance due to accretion
Decrease in dust shattering

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2b shows the dependence of various quantities on the UV radiation field intensity (x). Which of the following statements is **incorrect**?
choices: Higher UV radiation intensities suppress the H2 fraction at low metallicities.
The CO fraction is less sensitive to x at high metallicities where dust shielding is dominant.
The XCO-Z relation is independent of x.
Dust shielding can create favorable conditions for CO formation even at high x.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the rate coefficient RH2,dust in Equation (6) describe?
choices: The rate of CO formation on dust grains.
The rate of CO dissociation by UV radiation.
The rate of H2 formation on dust grains.
The rate of H2 dissociation by cosmic rays.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation (6) shows that the rate of H2 formation is directly proportional to:
choices: The gas temperature.
The material density of dust.
The fourth moment of the grain size distribution.
The escape probability of photons.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the optical depth TLW,i in Equation (12) represent?
choices: The optical depth of dust component i at visible wavelengths.
The optical depth of gas component i at Lyman-Werner wavelengths.
The optical depth of dust component i at Lyman-Werner wavelengths.
The column density of dust component i.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the grain size affect the optical depth (TLW) at the Lyman-Werner band according to Equation (12)?
choices: Smaller grains have a larger optical depth per unit dust mass compared to larger grains.
Larger grains have a larger optical depth per unit dust mass compared to smaller grains.
Grain size has no effect on the optical depth at the Lyman-Werner band.
The effect of grain size on TLW is negligible compared to the effect of dust composition.
